epd_metadata.product_group_classification: UN CPC 375 (Articles of concrete, cement and plaster)

third_party_verifier_contact.address: Suite 2600, 101 Marietta St NW, Atlanta, Georgia 30303, USA

epd_metadata.review_chair: Claudia A. Peña, University of Concepcién, Chile

lca_study_organisation_contact.address: Level 3, Greenhouse, 180 George Street, Sydney NSW 2000 Australia

product_description.description: VX321CLS 32 MPa 10mm Celestial EXP CONC Decorative
product_description.dangerous_goods_classification: Non-Dangerous Goods according to the Australian Code for the Transport of Dangerous Goods by Road and Rail
product_description.svhc_content: None of the products contain one or more substances that are listed in the “Candidate List of Substances of Very High Concern for authorisation”.
product_description.packaging: Delivered in bulk with no packaging

lca_information.scope: cradle to gate (modules A1-A3) with options, modules A4-A5, modules C1-C4 and module D
background_data_sources: Product specific EPDs for cements, admixtures, pigments and fibres
Australian National Life Cycle Inventory Database (AusLCI v1.42) (2023)
manual_impact_categories: Use of renewable primary energy resources used as raw materials
Use of non-renewable primary energy excluding non-renewable primary energy resources used as raw materials
lca_information.allocation: Intermediate flows allocated physically based on weight (quarries) or based on m3 of concrete (batching plant). Economic allocation used when physical allocation not possible. Fly ash and silica fumes are waste products and burden-free. Ground granulated blast furnace slag allocated economically.
lca_information.cut_off_criteria: Environmental impact from infrastructure, construction, production equipment, and tools not directly consumed in production are not accounted for. Personnel-related impacts are also excluded. No energy or mass flows, except packaging of materials, were excluded.
lca_information.data_quality: All data sources were scored good or very good. Background data sources updated within 10 years as required under PCR 2019:14.
lca_information.system_boundaries: Cradle to gate (A1-A3) with options, modules A4-A5, modules C1-C4 and module D. Life cycle stages B1-B7 not declared.

electricity_mix.mix: Black coal (75%), photovoltaic (17%), natural gas (3%), hydropower (3%), others (2%)
Black coal (71%), natural gas (12%), photovoltaic (8%), oil (4%), others (5%)
Wind power (61%), natural gas (34%), photovoltaic (4%), others (1%)
Natural gas (44%), brown coal (41%), wind power (8%), hydropower (3%), others (4%)
Natural gas (65%), wind power (26%), black coal (8%), others (1%)

deconstruction.process: Physical process of drilling and removing the concrete using hydraulic excavator

end_of_life.notes: 100% of the products (2,400 kg) are assumed to be separately collected during deconstruction. 80% recycled, 20% landfilled.

carbon_emission_context.2050_target_net_zero: All new construction materials need to be net zero by 2050 (World Green Building Council).
carbon_emission_context.carbonation_note: CO2 absorption (carbonation) during the life cycle of concrete is not considered in this EPD and is not reflected in the results tables. Refer to BS EN 16757:2017 for calculation methodology.

recycled_materials_handling.allocation_approach: Co-products are considered as co-products of their production process and impacts are allocated according to PCR 2019:14. Fly ash and silica fume treated as waste materials (only transport impacts included). Slag allocated based on economic value.
recycled_materials_handling.background_data_used: Default background data from LCA databases (AusLCI, ecoinvent) used to model co-products.
recycled_materials_handling.recycled_aggregate_use: End-of-life recyclers process waste concrete into recycled aggregate, which can replace virgin coarse aggregate for various applications.

references: Australian Life Cycle Inventory Database Initiative (AusLCI). (2023)
Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water. (2023). National Waste Report 2022.
EPD International. (2024). General Programme Instructions (GPI) for the International EPD System V£.0.
EPD International. (2024). Product Category Rules for Construction Products and Construction Services, PCR2019:14 V1.3.4.
Man Yu, Thomes Wiedmann, Robert Crawford, Catriona Tait, ‘The Carbon Footprint of Australia's Construction Sector’, Procedia Engineering, Volume 180, 2017.
